tags: sorry for the poor answer anon!
book stuff is not my forte
summary: Hey, I just saw that the author had said that book!Sansa was "an unreliable narrator" and that the fact that she's twisted her...
question: Hey, I just saw that the author had said that book!Sansa was "an unreliable narrator" and that the fact that she's twisted her memory and she thinks that the Hound has kissed her would serve a future plot. What do you think it means? I'm a little afraid by the differences between bookSansa ans showSansa.
answer:
Hi!

Sometimes I wonder whether Sansa remembers a kiss because what the Hound did to her was horrible, but most would brush it off and say he didn’t do anything. It was a violation. He did assault her and he was being inappropriate, but women are constantly told that our discomfort means nothing. That men harassing us means nothing. By imagining he stole a kiss, she can justify her own feelings of discomfort and being violated. 

If that’s the case… I find that not a great choice of the author. It’s a tricky subject since we struggle as it is with people screaming “falsely accused!” whenever a woman comes forward about sexual assault and abuse, and I don’t trust GRRM to do a good job with it.

I find it more likely that the Hound did kiss Sansa (and maybe even groped her) and that it was so traumatizing for her she blocked it out and only remembered it later on. Perhaps Marillion and Littlefinger triggered the memory with their groping and kissing. Especially the Marillion/Hound scenes are similar.

The Hound is drunk, forces her onto the bed, and threatens her with a knife because he wants a song. Marillion is drunk, comes to her bed, caresses her thigh, gropes her breast, and says he’ll sing to her with his body. And if you can sing with your body, perhaps the song the Hound stole was a kiss.

Blocking out traumatic memories is a common coping mechanism. And when the Hound tells Arya about that night, he doesn’t go into specifics so his statement neither confirms nor denies a kiss.

However, I think that makes sense more from a Watsonian point of view, because if I look at this quote:

[GRRM is asked about Sansa misremembering the name of Joffrey’s sword.]

“The Lion’s Paw / Lion’s Tooth business, on the other hand, is intentional. A small touch of the unreliable narrator. I was trying to establish that the memories of my viewpoint characters are not infallible. Sansa is simply remembering it wrong. A very minor thing (you are the only one to catch it to date), but it was meant to set the stage for a much more important lapse in memory. You will see, in A STORM OF SWORDS and later volumes, that Sansa remembers the Hound kissing her the night he came to her bedroom… but if you look at the scene, he never does. That will eventually mean something, but just now it’s a subtle touch, something most of the readers may not even pick up on.” (source)

it does sound as if the kiss was only a false memory.

But what that would mean or foreshadow, I don’t know. Perhaps the unkiss has less to do with the Hound and more to do with Sansa’s memory in general. She didn’t remember the name of a sword, and she thought she’d been kissed because GRRM is laying the foundation for a much bigger lapse in memory he doesn’t want to seem out of the blue.

I know some think it’s Jonsa related. I’ve seen theories about a possible pre-canon Jonsa kiss that she’s forgotten. That it foreshadows that. It’s not a theory I’m fond of, though, because it would squick me the heck out, so I’ve not delved deeper into it.

There are also theories that a newly resurrected Jon won’t remember Sansa once she turns up at the Wall–especially not if she goes by Alayne and has dark hair. So perhaps GRRM is building up for Sansa to not remember Jon either. It’s been a few long years, in which they’ve grown up and changed, and her not recognizing him at first isn’t impossible. Perhaps GRRM wants them to fall in love “at first sight” until they’re introduced and Sansa realizes who Jon is, only then it’s too late. If Jonsa is happening, I find that a likely theory.

But who knows. All I know is that it’s not foreshadowing a S/nsan ending. I don’t think the text supports one, I don’t think the show supports one, and from what I’ve seen of GRRM in interviews, it doesn’t sound as if he has a S/nsan endgame in mind.

Thanks for the ask!

summary: a few years later, the most well-informed person i knew told me that this girl without wealth, lands, or armies had somehow...
caption: a few years later, the most well-informed person i knew told me that this girl without wealth, lands, or armies had somehow acquired all three in a very short span of time, along with three dragons. he thought she was our last, best chance to build a better world. i thought you were worth meeting, at the very least.

reblog.comment: a few years later, the most well-informed person i knew told me that this girl without wealth, lands, or armies had somehow acquired all three in a very short span of time, along with three dragons. he thought she was our last, best chance to build a better world. i thought you were worth meeting, at the very least.

the family behind us was crazy
summary:
Sansa, stirring her tea: do you think they had tea back when Jesus was a thing?
Rickon, sipping his tea: probably not
Sansa:...
body:
Sansa, stirring her tea: do you think they had tea back when Jesus was a thing?
Rickon, sipping his tea: probably not
Sansa: why?
Rickon, looking at her over the rim of his cup: because if God wanted tea he'd have given it to fuckin Jesus

dialogue.name: Sansa, stirring her tea
dialogue.label: Sansa, stirring her tea:
dialogue.phrase: do you think they had tea back when Jesus was a thing?
